title-group.article-title: Gap-junction-mediated Communication in Human Periodontal Ligament Cells

abstract.p: Periodontal tissue homeostasis depends on a complex cellular network that conveys cell-cell communication. Gap junctions (GJs), one of the intercellular communication systems, are found between adjacent human periodontal ligament (hPDL) cells; however, the functional GJ coupling between hPDL cells has not yet been elucidated. In this study, we investigated functional gap-junction-mediated intercellular communication in isolated primary hPDL cells. SEM images indicated that the cells were in contact with each other via dendritic processes, and also showed high anti-connexin43 (Cx43) immunoreactivity on these processes. Gap-junctional intercellular communication (GJIC) among hPDL cells was assessed by fluorescence recovery after a photobleaching (FRAP) analysis, which exhibited dye coupling between hPDL cells, and was remarkably down-regulated when the cells were treated with a GJ blocker. Additionally, we examined GJs under hypoxic stress. The fluorescence recovery and expression levels of Cx43 decreased time-dependently under the hypoxic condition. Exposure to GJ inhibitor or hypoxia increased RANKL expression, and decreased OPG expression. This study shows that GJIC is responsible for hPDL cells and that its activity is reduced under hypoxia. This is consistent with the possible role of hPDL cells in regulating the biochemical reactions in response to changes in the hypoxic environment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The periodontal ligament (PDL) is a soft connective tissue that is situated between the cementum and alveolar bone to sustain teeth and preserve tissue homeostasis. It is thought to play a role in sensing mechanical stress on the teeth (Zhao et al., 2002; Seo et al., 2004) and appears to influence site-specific remodeling of the alveolar bone via the biochemical responses to stress such as masticatory and orthodontic forces (Takano-Yamamoto et al., 1994). Nevertheless, the role of intercellular communication between PDL cells has not been well-characterized, although it is widely accepted that such communication among osteoblasts, osteoclasts, and osteocytes is deeply involved in the regulation of bone modeling and remodeling (Civitelli, 2008).

Gap junctions (GJs), composed of connexin (Cx) subunit proteins, are known to comprise one of the intercellular communication systems which allow for electrical and metabolic coupling between adjacent cells (Flagg-Newton et al., 1979). In spite of the fact that Cx proteins have already been identified in PDL cells (Beertsen and Everts, 1980; Yamaoka et al., 2000), their distribution and detailed relationship to the cell morphology are not fully understood. Moreover, there is currently no direct evidence that Cx proteins form functional GJs among PDL cells.

The mechanical force exerted by orthodontic tooth movement causes distortion of the cells in the PDL. Since the PDL is a highly vascularized soft connective tissue that occupies from 4% to 47% of the tissue volume (Blaushild et al., 1992; Sims et al., 1996), these alterations affect both the blood supply and oxygen transport in the local environment of the PDL cells (Gaengler and Merte, 1983; Packman et al., 2007). It has been unclear whether such changes affect GJ coupling. In this report, we describe the occurrence of functional gap-junctional intercellular communication (GJIC) between isolated human PDL cells, using fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) analysis. In addition, we examined the effects of hypoxic stress on the GJIC in PDL cells to understand how the GJIC among PDL cells responds to the low-oxygen conditions that develop on the compression side during orthodontic tooth movement (Khouw and Goldhaber, 1970).

sec.title: Isolation and Culture of hPDL Cells
sec.p: With approval of the ethics committee, intact permanent teeth were collected from healthy patients undergoing orthodontic treatment at Okayama University Hospital. Ten premolars from 10 healthy donors (three male and seven female donors), aged 15 to 40 yrs, were used in the present study, and hPDL cells were isolated from the teeth as described previously (Kawanabe et al., 2010). The isolated hPDL cells were maintained in alpha-modified Minimum Essential Medium (α-MEM; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) with 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (HIFBS; HyClone, Logan, UT, USA) and penicillin/streptomycin (100 U/mL and 100 µg/mL, respectively; Invitrogen). The cells were fed twice a week by replacement of half of the media.

sec.title: Cx43 Staining and CLS Images
sec.p: The hPDL cells were fixed with 3% paraformaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) for 10 min, then permeabilized by 0.5% saponin in PBS for 10 min. After 3 washes with PBS, the cells were incubated overnight at 4°C with a 1:200 dilution of mouse monoclonal anti-Cx43 (BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA) in PBS containing 1% BSA. Subsequently, the cells were stained for 24 hrs at 4°C with Alexa 488-conjugated secondary antibody (Molecular Probes Inc., Eugene, OR, USA) for mouse IgG in PBS containing 1% BSA. After being rinsed with PBS, cells were stained overnight at 4°C with a 1:100 dilution of Texas red-X-conjugated phalloidin (Molecular Probes) in PBS containing 1% BSA. The samples were washed twice in PBS, mounted on glass slides with fluorescence mounting medium (Dako, Carpinteria, CA, USA), and observed with a 60 X fluorescence objective mounted on an inverted microscope. Fluorescence images of cells were acquired with a FLUOVIEW FV500 confocal laser scanning microscopy system (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM)
sec.p: We used SEM (DS-720; Topcon Corp., Tokyo, Japan) to study the hPDL cell structures. Isolated hPDL cells were fixed with 4% glutaraldehyde for 10 min, post-fixed in McDonald’s osmium-potassium ferricyanide mixture [0.5% OsO4 plus 0.8% K3Fe (CN)] for 15 min, washed in buffer, and immersed in 0.15% tannic acid for 1 to 2 min. After being rinsed in water, the specimens were dehydrated in ethanol, subjected to critical-point-drying, and then gold-coated by means of an ion sputter (JFC- 1100E; JEOL, Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: FRAP Analysis
sec.p: GJIC was monitored by a quantitative FRAP analysis, as described previously (Ishihara et al., 2008). After loading of Calcein-AM (Molecular Probes) onto the hPDL cells, images were acquired pre-bleaching, immediately afterward, and at 30-second intervals after bleaching in each experiment. The FRAP data were normalized and calculated as described previously (Ishihara et al., 2013).

sec.title: Induction of Hypoxia
sec.p: Hypoxia experiments were performed for the indicated time periods in a humidified triple gas model BL-40M incubator (BIO-LABO, Tokyo, Japan) calibrated to deliver 5% CO2, 2% O2, and 93% N2 at 37°C (Kondo et al., 2002).

sec.title: Western Blot Analysis
sec.p: SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) and Western transfer of proteins were performed as described previously (Kubota et al., 2004). Briefly, a 20-µg quantity of extracted proteins was separated by SDS-PAGE (in a 10% acrylamide gel) and transferred onto a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Richmond, CA, USA). The membranes were then blocked with 1% skim milk in Tris-buffered saline, labeled with antibodies against hypoxia-inducible factor-1 alpha (HIF-1α; R&D), Cx43 (BD), and actin (Sigma). The blots were visualized by means of an enhanced chemiluminescence analysis system (GE Healthcare, Buckinghamshire, UK).

sec.title: Real-time Reverse-transcription Polymerase Chain-reaction (RT-PCR)
sec.p: RNA purification and the RT-PCR analysis were performed as described previously (Kawanabe et al., 2010). The gene-specific primers used in the present study were as follows:
Human Apelin (GenBank accession no. BC021104.1) primer sequence (50 bp): (sense) 5′-CTCCTGCTGCTCTGGCTC TC-3′; (antisense) 5′-ATCAGGGACCCTCCACACAC-3′
Human receptor activator of NF-B ligand (RANKL) (GenBank accession no. AF019047) primer sequence (136 bp): (sense) 5′-TATGCCAACATTTGCTTTCG-3′; (antisense) 5′-TGGTG CTTCCTCCTTTCATC-3′
Human osteoprotegerin (OPG) (GenBank accession no. U94332) primer sequence (91 bp): (sense) 5′-TGAGGAGGCA TTCTTCAGGT-3′; (antisense) 5′-TACTTTGGTGCCAGGC AAAT-3′
Human 18S ribosomal RNA (GenBank accession no. X03205) primer sequence (260 bp): (sense) 5′-CATTCGAAC GTCTGCCCTAT-3′; (antisense) 5′-CCTCCAATGGATCCTC GTTA-3′.

sec.title: Measurement of the Gap Junction Area
sec.p: The GJ area was analyzed as described previously (Sugawara et al., 2008). The outline of the cell area was determined by phalloidin staining, and the GJ area was determined by anti-Cx43 staining. The average ratio of the total GJ area to the total cell area was calculated with the Win ROOF software program (MITANI Corporation, Fukui, Japan). Fluorescent images were converted to binary images for the measurement of the area. To generate the binary models of the total GJ area, we determined the threshold for the binary models to be more than 30 gray levels.

sec.title: Reagents
sec.p: The GJ inhibitor, 18 alpha-glycyrrhetinic acid (18α-GA) (Davidson and Baumgarten, 1988), and hypoxia mimetic compound, desferoxamine (DFO) (Wang and Semenza, 1993), were purchased from Sigma. The effects of 18α-GA on gap junction coupling are thought to act indirectly on the GJs through a series of phosphorylation changes in Cx43 proteins, resulting in the inhibition of GJs (Ciovacco et al., 2009). The drugs were present in the medium throughout the experiment.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Student’s t test or Tukey’s multiple-comparison test was used to perform statistical analysis, with a statistical analysis software program (JMP, SAS Institute Inc., Tokyo, Japan). Values of p < .05 were considered to be significant.

sec.title: Morphological Analysis of Cell-Cell Contact in Isolated hPDL Cells
sec.p: We used the previously reported procedure to isolate hPDL cells from healthy first premolars extracted prior to orthodontic treatment (Figs. 1A-1C). We transferred the cells at a concentration of 10,000 cells/mL, and performed the experiments.

caption.p: The characteristics of isolated hPDL cells. (A) A schematic diagram showing the isolation of the primary human PDL cells. (B) The primary human PDL cells one day after isolation. Bar = 100 µm. (C) The primary human PDL cells 14 days after isolation. The cells had reached confluence. Bar = 400 µm. (D) SEM image of the primary human PDL cells. Bar = 10 µm. (E) A magnified image of a region of interest (ROI) from (D). Bar = 500 nm. (F) Triple-label fluorescence staining of human primary PDL cells with anti-Cx43, Texas Red phalloidin, and Hoechst 33342. The red channel shows the PDL cell cytoskeleton stained with Texas Red phalloidin, and green staining shows anti-Cx43-positive sites. The nuclei were stained with Hoechst 33342 blue dye. Bar = 30 µm. (G) A magnified image of a ROI from (F). Cx43-reactive sites are observed as serial dots or linear staining along the cell processes (arrows). Bar = 10 µm.

sec.p: SEM images revealed that adjacent hPDL cells extended dendrite-like structures and connected to each other at the ends of the structure (Figs. 1D, 1E), indicating that hPDL cells establish contact with each other via dendritic structures.

sec.title: hPDL Cells Exhibit Cx43 Immunoreactivity at Interfaces between Cells
sec.p: In primary culture, we investigated Cx43 immunoreactivity to examine the GJ distribution in hPDL cells. Immunofluorescent images showed the presence of gap-binding protein, Cx43 (indicated with arrows), localized between hPDL cells (Figs. 1F, 1G). The presence of Cx43, which composes GJs on the dendritic structure, suggests that intercellular GJs are present between isolated hPDL cells.

sec.title: FRAP Analysis Shows Gap-junctional Intercellular Communication in Primary hPDL Cells
sec.p: We used a FRAP analysis to examine the functional intercellular communication via GJs in isolated hPDL cells. First, we performed fluorescent staining of isolated hPDL cells with Calcein-AM (Fig. 2A). The rapid recovery of fluorescence into photobleached cells and connected processes was observed within 300 sec after photobleaching (Figs. 2B, 2C). The fluorescence intensity recovered up to 60.1 ± 3.2% of the pre-bleached level (n = 25). Treatment with 18α-GA, a GJ inhibitor, dose-dependently reduced the recovery of fluorescence in bleached cells (Figs. 2B, 2D). The additional experiment confirmed that the recovery of fluorescence took place via gap-junction-mediated transport through the cell process (Figs. 2F-2H). These results suggest that there is functional activity of the GJIC between hPDL cells.

caption.p: FRAP analysis of primary hPDL cells. The hPDL cells were loaded with 5.0 μM Calcein-AM in the medium for 15 min. After removal of excess dye, individual hPDL cells were selected and photobleached. (A) Fluorescently labeled and DIC images of primary hPDL cells. Bar = 50 μm. (B) Recovery of the fluorescence intensity. The data are expressed as means ± SE. The asterisks indicate a significant difference at each time-point (***p < .0001, photobleached cell vs. 18 α-GA-pre-treated cell). (C-E) Images of fluorescently labeled PDL cells from the FRAP analysis. Serial images were taken pre-bleaching, immediately after bleaching, and at 30-second intervals during fluorescence recovery. (C) A photobleached cell. (D) A cell treated with 5.0 µM 18 α-GA for 60 min at 37°C before FRAP analysis. (E) A reference cell, scanned from an unbleached area. (F) Fluorescence image of living hPDL cells. The numbered cells in the fluorescent image correspond to the cells assessed in panel G. (G) A representative example of the fluorescence intensity plots in a bleached cell and adjacent cells. Each line represents the time-course of the fluorescence intensity of individual hPDLs in the corresponding figure in panel F. In the coupled cell pairs (Cells 1 and 2), a significant decrease in fluorescence was observed in the unbleached cell (Cell 2), indicating that dye is transferred to the photobleached cell (Cell 1) via a cell process as fluorescence recovery occurs. (H) Serial fluorescence images of the primary hPDL cells before being bleached, immediately after being bleached (0), and at 150 and 300 sec after the initiation of monitoring. Bar = 20 µm.

sec.title: Hypoxia Down-regulates GJIC in hPDL Cells
sec.p: We then examined how the hPDL protein or gene expression levels responded to hypoxic stress. As shown in Figs. 3A and 3B, hPDL cells cultured under hypoxic conditions (2% O2) exhibited a time-dependent increase in the expression of hypoxia markers, HIF-1α protein and Apelin mRNA (Ronkainen et al., 2007). Pharmacological activation of hypoxic stress by DFO also increased Apelin mRNA expression (Fig. 3C). These results confirmed that hPDL cells responded to hypoxic conditions when incubated under 2% oxygen or in the presence of DFO.

caption.p: Hypoxia-mediated changes of GJIC and Cx43 protein expression in primary hPDL cells. (A) The expression of Hif-1α in hPDL cells was assessed by a Western blot analysis at the indicated times after exposure to hypoxic stress. After hypoxic stress, the Hif-1α protein expression increased in a time-dependent manner. (B-C) The detection of Apelin mRNA in hPDL cells after exposure to hypoxia stress (B) and 100 μM DFO treatment (C) as determined by real-time PCR analysis. The data are expressed as the means ± SD. The asterisks indicate a significant difference (*p < .05, **p < .01; Tukey’s multiple-comparison test). (D-E) Changes in fluorescence recovery among hPDL cells exposed to different DFO levels. (D) The time-dependent effect of DFO on the recovery of fluorescence intensity of photobleached hPDL cells. hPDL cells were incubated in medium in the presence of 100 μM DFO for 1 and 3 hrs. (E) The dose-dependent effect of DFO on the recovery of the fluorescence intensity of photobleached hPDL cells. The hPDL cells were incubated in medium for 3 hrs in the presence of DFO. The concentrations of DFO were 10 μM and 100 μM. The asterisks indicate a significant difference at each time-point (**p < .01; ***p < .0001 photobleached cell vs. DFO-pre-treated cell). (F) The GJ area of primary hPDL cells after treatment with 100 μM DFO. The blue line shows the GJ area of hPDL cells from a control group. The red line shows the GJ area of hPDL cells after treatment with 100 μM DFO. The GJ area of hPDL cells after treatment with DFO was decreased time-dependently. (G, H) The expression of Cx43 in hPDL cells was assessed by a Western blot analysis at the indicated times after exposure to hypoxic conditions, and after treatment with 100 μM DFO. The ratio of the intensity of the Cx43 bands was quantified by densitometry relative to the densitometric measurement of the actin band. After hypoxic stress and treatment with 100 μM DFO, Cx43 expression decreased in a time-dependent manner. The data are expressed as the means ± SE of more than 4 separate samples. The asterisks indicate significant differences (*p < .05; ***p < .01; Tukey’s multiple-comparison test).

sec.p: Subsequently, we used FRAP analysis to examine the regulation of GJIC under hypoxic stress. DFO application dose- and time-dependently decreased the fluorescent recovery (Figs. 3D, 3E) in hPDL cells. These results indicate that there is a reduction of GJIC under hypoxic stress.

sec.title: Effects of Hypoxia on the Cx43 Expression of hPDL Cells
sec.p: The effect of hypoxia on hPDL Cx43 protein distribution and quantity was determined by immunofluorescent staining and a Western blot analysis. Using fluorescence microscopy and the Win ROOF software program, we found that the Cx43 area in hPDLs was decreased in a time-dependent manner after treatment with DFO (Fig. 3F, p < .05, n = 15). This suggested that there was a decrease in Cx43 protein expression under hypoxic conditions. Densitometric measurements of the results of the Western blot analyses were performed to confirm whether the reduction in the immunolabeling was due to altered expression levels of Cx43. Hypoxic exposure or DFO treatment time-dependently decreased the Cx43 protein levels in hPDL cells (p < .05; Figs. 3G, 3H). These findings suggest that the reduction in Cx43 immunoreactivity is most likely due to altered expression levels of this protein under hypoxic conditions, and not to conformational changes in the surface structures of Cx43.

sec.title: Blockade of GJ Formation or Exposure to Hypoxia Increases RANKL Expression and Decreases OPG mRNA Expression
sec.p: To examine further the functional role of GJ in hPDL cell behavior, we measured the levels of RANKL and OPG mRNA in the absence or presence of a GJ inhibitor. Treatment with 1.0 µM of 18α-GA increased the RANKL mRNA expression in hPDL cells. The inhibitor also caused a reduction in OPG mRNA expression (Fig. 4A). Similar results were obtained following exposure to hypoxia (Fig. 4B).

caption.p: Effects of a GJ inhibitor on the expression of RANKL and OPG in hPDL cells. (A) The cells were cultured in the presence of 1.0 µM of 18α-GA for 7 days. (B) The cells were cultured under hypoxic conditions (2% O2) for 7 days. The mRNA levels of RANKL and OPG were analyzed by real-time PCR. The data are expressed as the mean ± SD. The asterisks indicate significant differences (*p < .05, **p < .01; Student’s t test).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we demonstrated the presence of GJIC between hPDL cells and showed that there was a decrease in GJIC and Cx43 expression by primary hPDL cells when they were cultured under hypoxic stress. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first evidence that GJs are responsible for intercellular communication between adjacent hPDL cells and that their activity is influenced by hypoxia.

Cx43 is the most abundant GJ protein forming GJ channels (Musil et al., 1990). Our morphological results with the anti-Cx43 antibody showed that Cx43 was predominantly distributed throughout the dendritic structure in a serial dot-like or linear fashion. We speculate that this expression pattern represents attachment of hPDL cell processes on the sides, as shown in our previous study in osteocytes (Kamioka et al., 2007). The FRAP analysis results of decreased fluorescence recovery in the presence of the GJ inhibitor suggest that GJs are functional in isolated hPDL cells. Furthermore, previous reports have shown that GJIC in the bone cell network contributes to bone formation and remodeling (Li et al., 1999; Donahue, 2000). The fact that the positions of PDL cells are well-suited to allow the cells to sense biophysical stress and communicate with other bone cells makes it conceivable that the signals sent via the GJs of PDL cells to the surrounding bone cell network play a role in bone remodeling.

The application of orthodontic tooth movement leads to compression of the PDL, resulting in localized hypoxia due to vascular constriction within the PDL (Gaengler and Merte, 1983; Kuitert et al., 1988; Packman et al., 2007). Consequently, the analysis of the hypoxia-induced regulation of the GJIC provides a better understanding of the biochemical processes associated with orthodontic tooth movement. We observed a decrease in Cx43 expression, leading to a reduced level of GJIC in hPDL cells cultured in a low-oxygen environment. Other investigators have shown an increase and/or decrease in Cx43 expression in response to hypoxic stress; however, the mechanism underlying this regulation remains unknown. Su et al. reported the role of Cx43 expressed on osteocytes in orthodontic tooth movement. It was demonstrated that Cx43 is significantly increased in osteocytes in the tension zones compared with the compression zones after exposure to force during experimental tooth movement (Su et al., 1997). In a recent study, Matsumoto and colleagues provided the first evidence showing that osteocytes are involved in osteoclastic bone resorption during orthodontic tooth movement (Matsumoto et al., 2013). Our present study demonstrated that the blockade of GJs or hypoxic stress increased RANKL mRNA expression and decreased OPG expression in hPDL cells, indicating either a positive influence of GJs on bone formation or a negative influence of GJs on bone resorption. Although further studies are needed to elucidate the precise role of GJIC in PDL cells, it can be speculated that hypoxia-induced regulation of GJ-mediated cell-cell communication plays a role in bone metabolism in the compression area of PDL during orthodontic tooth movement.

In conclusion, hPDL cells showed direct cell-cell contact via cell processes and functional communication with each other through GJ. Additionally, hypoxic stress decreased the GJIC, which was attributable to a decrease in Cx43, suggesting a possible role for these cells in the regulation of biochemical reactions in response to hypoxia.
